data.title: 350 Japanese Counters Grouped by How Useful They Are
data.meta_description: We've put together a list of 350 Japanese counters grouped by usefulness. That way, you can learn the counters that get used most often.
data.text:
In our main Japanese counters article, you learned what counters are and how to use them. You also learned that around 500 counters exist, though not all of them are in common (or even uncommon) use. We took this list and reduced the number to 350, then categorized them by how useful they are.

Although this Japanese counters list is extremely thorough, you don't have to learn everything here. You can get away with memorizing anywhere between two, nineteen, or sixty-six counters, depending on what your goals are. Here's how we broke things down:

Absolutely Must-Know Counters: 2

Must-Know Counters: 17

Common Counters: 47

Somewhat Common Counters: 205

Rare But Interesting Counters: 22

Gairaigo Counters: 57

One more note is that some of the "counters" in here are actually "units" having to do with time, weight, speed, etc. But, since those units work grammatically the same as counters and mostly follow the same reading rules, we included them on our counters list. Plus, they're all counting something, technically, be it days, hours, minutes, etc.

Prerequisite: You'll want to make sure you know how to read hiragana. If you get to the gairaigo counters, you'll need to know how to read katakana as well. There will also be times we mention the "kango/wago/gairaigo counting method." You can learn all three Japanese numbering systems in our Counting in Japanese article. Knowing the kanji for the numbers will help too. In our example sentences and explanations, we equally use Arabic numerals (1, 2, 3) and Japanese kanji (ä¸€, äºŒ, ä¸‰), since both are quite common in Japanese.

around 500 counters exist, though not all of them are in common (or even uncommon) use.

As this is a reference guide, we highly recommend you CTRL/CMD+F to find the counter you're looking for. If we have an individual (and more thorough) separate article for the counter, there will be a link to take you there. We recommend reading those individual counters articles when you can, as they go into much greater detail than we're able to here. In this article, we just give you an overview of each counter without going too deep.

To assist you in your studies more, we've also created a complimentary spreadsheet that contains all of the counters in this article plus how to count with them. To download it, just sign up for our email list. We'll use it to notify you about new Japanese language articles, Japanese resources, article giveaways (such as this one), as well as any sales and new product releases.

2 Absolutely Must-Know Japanese Counters

There are only two absolutely must-know Japanese counters. They are ã€œã¤ and å€‹ (ã“). Why only these two? In a way, they're magical. They can be used to count just about anything. If you are lazy, or if you don't know the correct counter for something, you can just use these and it will (probably) make sense.

The ã€œã¤ Counter

I've listed ã€œã¤ as a counter, but actually it's just the original wago (Japanese) form of counting. If you don't know what wago counting is (it's not ichi, ni, san), check out our How To Count In Japanese guide.

Probably thanks to the fact that this "counter" is just numbers, it can be used to count just about anything in Japanese. Things with shape, things without shape, abstract things, number order, little kids' ages, thoughts, ideas, and pretty much everything else. It's extremely versatile and helpful for when you don't know the specific counter for something.

Counts: just about everything.

Although the explanation "it can count anything" is pretty right on the money (and self-explanatory), you can read more about the counter ã€œã¤ here.

The å€‹ (ã“) Counter

It's important to compare the counter å€‹ with ã€œã¤ to understand its limitations.

å€‹ is just the kango, a.k.a. Chinese version of ã€œã¤. Like ã€œã¤, you can count almost anything with this counter, though it's slightly less versatile. Think of it this way: if the thing you're counting has a boundary to it, you can use å€‹. If it doesn't have a distinct boundary, or it's too abstract, it's an age, or it's related to number order, it's more common to use ã€œã¤.

Counts: pretty much anything with a distinct shape or boundary.

It's important to compare the counter å€‹ with ã€œã¤ to understand its limitations (it's only almost as flexible as ã€œã¤), so I'd recommend you read our article on the counter å€‹.

17 Must-Know Japanese Counters

Congratulations! You've walked through the "Absolutely Must-Know Counters" group only to find yourself in the very similar "Must-Know Counters" group. We'll be covering seventeen Japanese counters in this section. The first eight follow regular pronunciation rules (æœ¬, æš, åŒ¹, é ­, ç¾½, å†Š, å°, åˆ†, å¹´ and å›), the other seven (æ—¥, äºº, æœˆ, æ™‚, æ™‚é–“, éš, and æ­³) don't. For more information on pronunciation rules when counting with counters, look for our table in the big Japanese counters guide.

æœ¬ (ã»ã‚“)

Usually, the æœ¬ counter is taught as the counter for "stick-shaped or long" things. That covers most of its use, but æœ¬ can actually count seven different categories of things, which we broke down in great detail in our æœ¬ counter guide.

Counts: pens, pencils, asparagus, soba, darts, firewood, trees, bamboo, cords, threads, dumplings, water wells, injections, folding fans, eels, tails, nail clippers, icicles, fishing rods, film, chimneys, tenugui, trains, sashes, telephone poles, cylindrical batteries, bottles, tires, ribbons, cacti, soda cans, and much, much more.

æš (ã¾ã„)

The main thing that ã€œæš does is count flat things. With that, you'll be fine most of the time. This counter counts a really wide variety of things. Like æœ¬, it is quite versatile considering it's a pretty specific counter. We wrote about the four categories of the counter æš in our æš counter article.

Counts: paper, photos, rafts, bath mats, shells, playing cards, credit cards, t-shirts, pants, other clothes, dust cloths, walls, a single serving of soba, a single serving of gyoza, and much, much more.

åŒ¹ (ã²ã)

The counter ã€œåŒ¹ is used to count small or medium-sized animals. If you can pick the animal, fish, bird, or insect up, you can probably count it with åŒ¹. For larger animals, é ­ (ã¨ã†) is the more common counter, though for some reason Godzilla is still counted with åŒ¹. Curious why? Read our article on the Japanese counter åŒ¹ for a much more thorough explanation.

Counts: dogs, cats, monkeys, fish, prawns, shrimps, lobsters, wolves, rabbits (unless they're counted with ç¾½), mosquitoes, shellfish, deer, worms, caterpillars, silkworms, earthworms, frogs, snails, crabs, tortoises, turtles, octopuses, animals, insects, dragonflies, sea otters, ogres, monsters, naughty children, animal-like people, etc.

é ­ (ã¨ã†)

As we mentioned in the åŒ¹ section, é ­ is generally used for large-sized animals. If you can't pick the animal up, chances are you could count it with é ­. That being said, there are some exceptions where é ­ is used for smaller animals, and åŒ¹ gets used for bigger ones (like Godzilla). For more details and information on exceptions, read our article on the é ­ counter.

Counts: cows, horses, livestock, elephants, gorillas, whales, camels, tigers, "professional" animals, insects on display, animals for sale, etc.

ç¾½ (ã‚)

The counter ç¾½ is used to count birds. ç¾½ by itself means wings, though you shouldn't use it to count insects. The only weird thing: you can count rabbits with ç¾½ as well! Learn all about this counter in the in-depth article we wrote about the counter ç¾½.

Counts: chickens, ostriches, peacocks, penguins, other birds, also rabbits, origami cranes, etc.

å†Š (ã•ã¤)

The counter å†Š is used to count books. From the kanji, you can see it looks just like a book from the side. Don't confuse this with the counter æœ¬ which, ironically, is not used to count books (even though the word æœ¬ means "book"). This is a pretty straightforward counter, but you can still learn more by reading the in-depth article we wrote about it.

Counts: books, book collections, albums, notebooks, memo pads, musical scores, catalogs, magazines, dictionaries, publications, documents, booklets, etc.

å° (ã ã„)

å° is used to count a variety of fairly unrelated things, making it somewhat less straightforward than your average counter. It is used to count platforms you can stand or put things on, machines, cars, large instruments, and more. Check out our å° counter article to learn more.

Counts: playground slides, beds, tables, couches, harps, pianos, cellos, cars, trucks, motors, washing machines, dryers, ovens, air conditioners, microwaves, cellular phones, keyboards, and more.

åˆ† (ãµã‚“)

åˆ† is technically a unit for minutes, but it looks and smells like a counter (it follows all the same grammatical and reading rules). For each åˆ† you count, another minute has been counted. To read more about this counter/unit, check out our in-depth article all about åˆ†.

Counts: minutes (time/degree)

æ—¥ (ã‹/ã«ã¡)

This is the counter for days. There's nothing particularly complicated about it, but the readings can be tricky because they are a mixture of wago and kango. You can learn all about it in our deep-dive article about the counter æ—¥.

Counts: days, specific days of the month

å¹´ (ã­ã‚“)

ï¼‘å¹´ã«ã¯ï¼“ï¼–ï¼•æ—¥ã‚ã‚‹ã€‚

There are 365 days in a year.

The å¹´ counter is used to count years (one year, two years, three years, etc.), but it can also be an ordinal number (first, second, third) for someone's grade in school. For example, ï¼‘å¹´ is grade one, ï¼’å¹´ is grade two, etc. That means the first year of high school/college/university would be ï¼‘å¹´, and a person who is in their first year is an ä¸€å¹´ç”Ÿ (ã„ã¡ã­ã‚“ã›ã„), or "first-year student." Unlike some of the other time-related Japanese counters, å¹´ just uses kango for its counting method. We cover all this in-depth in our giant article about the Japanese counter å¹´.

Counts: years, grades

å› (ã‹ã„)

å› is used to count the number of times something happens, or frequency. It's often translated to "times" because ï¼‘å› is "one time," ï¼‘ï¼ï¼å› is "one hundred times." This isn't a multiplier, though. If you ate dinner ï¼’å›, you just ate dinner twice, you didn't eat twice as much dinner, necessarily. You can read much more about the Japanese counter å› in our in-depth article.

Counts: the number of times something happens, chances, opportunities, revolutions, etc.

äºº (ã‚Š/ã«ã‚“)

The kanji äºº means "person." The counter äºº follows suit by counting numbers of people. Beyond people, it can also count things we treat like people, such as fairies, elves, and even your pets, if you treat them like family. It goes much deeper than that, and you can learn more in the article we wrote about the äºº counter.

It's also important to note that the first two people (ä¸€äººã€äºŒäºº) get counted using the wago counting method. Three people and up (ä¸‰äºº) are just counted in kango.

Counts: humans, people, angels, mermaids, Doraemon, humanoids, pets that are like family, etc.

æœˆ (ã¤ã/ãŒã¤)

æœˆ is a counter used to count the number of months ("10 months" is ï¼‘ï¼ãƒ¶æœˆ) as well as identify the calendar month ("October" is ï¼‘ï¼æœˆ). Depending on what you're counting or how it's used, the way it gets read (ã¤ã vs ã’ã¤ vs ãŒã¤) changes, so be aware of that. To read up on this counter, check out our full deep-dive into æœˆ.

Counts: months, calendar months

æ™‚ (ã˜)

Like åˆ† (minutes), this is not technically a counter, but instead a unit for hours. Usually, æ™‚ is translated to "o'clock" as in "twelve o'clock." There are some pronunciation exceptions you will need to consider too. This "counter" is extremely common and useful, so ideally you'll need to memorize the numbers 1â€“24 (you know, the number of hours that are in a day). Read all about the Japanese counter æ™‚ in our deep-dive article.

Counts: o'clock

æ™‚é–“ (ã˜ã‹ã‚“)

By itself the word æ™‚é–“ means "time." As a counter, æ™‚é–“ will count number of hours, as in "three hours" or "twenty-four hours." You can learn way more about this counter in our in-depth æ™‚é–“ article.

Counts: hours

éš (ã‹ã„)

The éš counter counts building floors. Which floor would you like to go up to? The 100th floor (ï¼‘ï¼ï¼éš) or the 3rd floor (ï¼“éš)? Or why don't you just forget all that and come on up to ï¼”ï¼’éš instead?

Take your knowledge of éš to the next level (or floor) by reading our in-depth write-up about it.

Counts: a building's floors

æ­³ (ã•ã„)

The æ­³ counter is used to count age. This works for people, animals, and more. Note that there is another (simpler) kanji for the same thing, which is æ‰. Technically they both make sense, but æ­³ is more correct, if you're able to use it.

Counts: age in years

47 Common Japanese Counters

This section covers the counters we deemed as quite "common" or "useful." Although they aren't part of the absolutely must-know list, they will enhance the quality of your day-to-day Japanese language life. They are still "common," after all. Some are going to be everyday use, while others are less common but important to know for formal or specific situations. At some point, you'll need to learn all of these if you're serious about becoming fluent in Japanese.

å†† (ãˆã‚“)

This is the unit for the Japanese currency, the yen. You'd use this to count an amount of yen.

Counts: yen

ç®‡æœˆ(ã‹ã’ã¤)

ç®‡æœˆ is the counter for the number of months. As in, "for three months" or "in three months." More often, you'll see the hiragana ã‹ or a small ãƒµ or ãƒ¶ instead of the kanji ç®‡, which is actually just an archaic version of the counter å€‹!.

Counts: number of months

ç®‡å›½ (ã‹ã“ã)

ç®‡å›½ is used to count the number of individual countries. If you're just generally counting countries, just the counter å›½ will be fine. ç®‡å›½ emphasizes that they are individual and different. The kanji ç®‡ is often written with the hiragana ã‹ or a small ãƒµ or ãƒ¶.

Counts: individual countries

ç®‡æ‰€ (ã‹ã—ã‚‡)

This counter is used to count places, spots, points, passages, etc. Basically any kind of place. The kanji ç®‡ is often written with the hiragana ã‹ or a small ãƒµ or ãƒ¶.

Counts: places, spots, points, passages, parts, typos, water supply points, movie theaters, shopping malls, toilets, mosquito bites, scars, broken parts of something, parts that need to be fixed, changed parts, dangerous areas, etc.

ç¼¶ (ã‹ã‚“)

This word means can (as in an aluminum can). Its reading is (coincidentally) "kan," and it can be used to count cans. The first two cans can be counted with either wago or kango numbers. "One can" is ï¼‘ç¼¶, read as either ã„ã£ã‹ã‚“ or ã²ã¨ã‹ã‚“. "Two cans" is ï¼’ç¼¶, read as either ã«ã‹ã‚“ or ãµãŸã‹ã‚“. From three cans and up you use the kango counting method. When a can is emptyâ€”or when it's a garbage canâ€”you'll generally want to use the counter å€‹ instead of ç¼¶.

Counts: soda cans, beer cans, tuna cans, bean cans, milk cans, spray cans, paint cans, tea leaves in tins, etc.

å·» (ã‹ã‚“)

ãƒ¯ãƒ³ãƒ”ãƒ¼ã‚¹ã‚’ï¼“ï¼’å·»è²·ã„æƒãˆãŸã€‚

I bought thirty-two volumes of One Piece.

This is used to count volumes of a series of books, videotapes, cassette tapes, etc. It can also be used as an ordinal number suffix to show which item in a series it is. For example, ãƒãƒªãƒ¼ãƒãƒƒã‚¿ãƒ¼ã®ï¼‘ï¼“å·»ç›® is "the thirteenth Harry Potter book in the series."

Counts: volumes of books, cassette tapes, videotapes, DVDs, etc. that are in a series, and scrolls.

æ›² (ãã‚‡ã)

The word æ›² just means song. When used as a counter, it can count the number of songs.

Counts: songs, music

åˆ‡ã‚Œ (ãã‚Œ)

åˆ‡ã‚‹ means "to cut." The counter åˆ‡ã‚Œ is used to count cut/sliced things (especially foods). You'll see this used to count slices of sashimi or filets of meat, for example.

Counts: sliced pieces of fish (including sashimi), slices of meat, mochi (rice cakes), slices of bread, slices of cake, slices of pizza, slices of okonomiyaki, cuts of cheese, etc.

å£ (ãã¡)

å£ by itself means "mouth." When used as a counter, it counts "bites." This is the main use case for this counter, but there are other meanings as well. Things like a set price of a contribution, submissions to a contest, bank accounts, and a "share" of insurance.

Counts: bites (e.g., "one bite of chicken"), sips (e.g., "one sip of strawberry milk"), swords, suspended temple bells, submissions to win a prize, the set price of a contribution, a set donation amount, shares of insurance

çµ„ (ãã¿)

The çµ„ counter is used to count a set, a group, or a pair of something. For one and two groups, use the wago reading (ã²ã¨ãã¿, ãµãŸãã¿). From three on up, just use kango (ã•ã‚“ãã¿, ã‚ˆã‚“ãã¿ and so on).

Counts: a couple of lovers, a couple of groups, a pair of earrings, a pair of gloves or mittens, a set of playing cards, a set of futon bedding, a set of stacked food boxes, a jacket and pants suit set, etc.

Quite commonly, you'll see çµ„ used to categorize classrooms too. When itâ€™s used this way, you just use kango. One class will be named ï¼’çµ„ï¼ˆã«ãã¿ï¼‰ (second class group), another ï¼˜çµ„ï¼ˆã¯ã¡ãã¿ï¼‰ (eighth class group). If you're watching Japanese TV or reading Japanese manga, and someone's going to school, this will surely show up!

Note that alphabets and words can also be paired up with ã€œçµ„ when used for a class group name. When paired with something else but numeral, the reading of çµ„ gets rendaku-ed, and becomes ãã¿ as in A çµ„ï¼ˆãã¿ï¼‰ (Class A) or ã‚­ãƒªãƒ³ çµ„ï¼ˆãã¿ï¼‰ (Class Giraffe).

Counts: as an ordinal number suffix for a classroom number.

ä»¶ (ã‘ã‚“)

The word ä»¶ means "a matter" or "a case." As a counter, it counts those "matters" and "cases." The definition is a bit vague, but that's because it covers a lot of categories. Check out the "counts" list for more details.

Counts: proposals, suggestions, legislative bills, agenda items, projects, plans, crimes, incidents, scandals, complaints, objections, contracts, agreements, emails, financing, loans, troubles, bankruptcies, page views, Internet access numbers, voice mail messages, etc.

è»’ (ã‘ã‚“)

The kanji itself means "eaves" (i.e., "eaves of a house"). As a counter it's used to count houses, buildings, shops, restaurants, farms, factories, and so on. It can also be used to count mailing addresses. If, for example, we sent WaniKani stickers to 100 people/addresses, we would say we sent stickers to ï¼‘ï¼ï¼è»’.

Counts: houses, shops, restaurants, warehouses, factories, farms, households, recipients, apartment buildings, apartments, hermitages, tenements, etc.

èª (ã”)

This counter is used to count words. For example, if this article has 30,000 words, you could say 30,000èª. Alternatively, you can use the gairaigo counter ãƒ¯ãƒ¼ãƒ‰, though I think èª is more common.

Counts: words

æ ¡ (ã“ã†)

æ ¡ is used to count the number of schools. It can also be used to count the number of proofreading (æ ¡æ­£) corrections.

Counts: schools, elementary schools, pre-schools, junior high schools, secondary schools, private schools, public schools, high schools, colleges, universities, cram schools, proofreading corrections, etc.

çš¿ (ã•ã‚‰)

çš¿ means "dish" or "plate," referring to dishes or plates of food. For empty plates, you can still use çš¿, but the counter æš will be more common for this. If you want to count individual pieces of food on the plate, you'll want to use å“ (ã—ãª). You can use çš¿ to count laboratory dishes as well (like the ones that grow bacteria). For one and two plates, use the wago reading (ã²ã¨ã•ã‚‰ã€ãµãŸã•ã‚‰). Three can be either (ã¿ã•ã‚‰ or ã•ã‚“ã•ã‚‰). From four on up, just use kango.

Counts: plates, dishes, lab dishes, food on a plate/dish, one serving of soba (usually cold), etc.

è©¦åˆ (ã—ã‚ã„)

The word è©¦åˆ means "game" (generally referring to a sports game). This counter counts these games. You'll especially see this counter used for Japanese sportsâ€”foreign sports may use the gairaigo counter ã‚²ãƒ¼ãƒ  instead.

Counts: games, matches

å“ (ã—ãª/ã²ã‚“)

å“ is used to count items, products, or dishes of food. In situations where it's pronounced ã—ãª, you'll want to use the wago counting method for one (ä¸€å“/ã²ã¨ã—ãª) and two (äºŒå“/ãµãŸã—ãª). After that it's all kango. When pronounced as ã²ã‚“, this counter just uses the kango counting method right from the start.

Counts: dishes of food, a meal's course dish, items, products

ç¤¾ (ã—ã‚ƒ)

The ç¤¾ counter is used to count companies (ä¼šç¤¾) or temples (ç¥ç¤¾).

Counts: companies, publishers, newspaper companies, shrines etc.

ç¨®é¡(ã—ã‚…ã‚‹ã„)

ç¨®é¡ means "variety," "kind," "type," etc., and the counter version is used to count those "kinds" of things.

Counts: kinds, varieties, types

é€± (ã—ã‚…ã†)

ï¼‘é€±é–“ãšã£ã¨é¢¨é‚ªã§å¯è¾¼ã‚“ã§ã„ãŸã€‚

I had a cold and was in bed all week.

é€± is used to count weeks. Most of the time, you'll want to add the suffix é–“ (ã‹ã‚“) which changes "week" to "for __ weeks." For example, ï¼’é€±é–“ would mean "for two weeks," and ï¼•é€±é–“ would mean "for five weeks."

If you add the ordinal number suffix ç›® to é€± it identifies which week you're talking about. ï¼“é€±ç›® means "the third week," and ï¼‘é€±ç›® means "the first week." Alternatively, you could add the ordinal number prefix ç¬¬ (ã ã„). ç¬¬ï¼‘é€± would mean "the first week" as well.

Counts: weeks

å‘¨ (ã—ã‚…ã†)

å‘¨ is used to count rounds. By that I mean circuits around a track, laps, revolutions, etc. Check out å›ã‚Š/å»»ã‚Š/å‘¨ã‚Š (all ã¾ã‚ã‚Š) for something similar.

Counts: the number of times you go around something, circuits, rounds, laps, rounds of golf, instances of traveling around something/somewhere, courses, revolutions etc.

è‰² (ã—ã‚‡ã/ã„ã‚)

The kanji/vocabulary of è‰² means "color." The counter version just counts number of colors. A rainbow, for example, consists of seven colors. That would be ä¸ƒè‰² (ãªãªã„ã‚ or ãªãªã—ã‚‡ã). Although the number of colors in a rainbow can be read two ways, generally when you count colors you'll just use the kango readings: ã„ã£ã—ã‚‡ã, ã«ã—ã‚‡ã, ã•ã‚“ã—ã‚‡ã, etc.

Counts: colors

å¸­ (ã›ã)

å¸­ means "seat," and the counter version just counts seats. In addition to this, it can be used to count meetings or entertainment performances and rankings in a competition or contest. I've heard people pronounce the first two å¸­s as ã²ã¨ã›ã and ãµãŸã›ã, but it's more correct to use the kango counting method for all of them.

Counts: seats, parties, banquets, performances, Rakugo performances, drinking parties, meetings, as an ordinal number suffix for ranking in a competition/contest, etc.

æˆ¦ (ã›ã‚“)

This kanji refers to a war, a battle, or a match. The counter version counts matches, fights, battles, or even sports game matches.

Counts: skirmishes in a war, sports fights, martial arts fights, real fights, matches, video game matches, sports games, games, board game matches, Chess matches, ShÅgi matches, etc.

è¶³ (ãã)

This kanji means foot/leg. As a counter it counts pairs of shoes, slippers, sandals, boots, socks, and so on. Basically things you put on your feet and legs.

Counts: shoes, socks, stockings, slippers, zÅri (Japanese sandals), tabi (Japanese socks), geta (wooden Japanese shoes), clogs, roller skates, rollerblades, ice skates, flip flops, boots, rain boots, sheets of dried squid, etc.

æŸ (ãŸã°)

æŸ means "a bunch," or "a bundle." Use wago for one and two bunches, either kango or wago for three bunches, and kango for four bunches and up. There's also another Japanese counter for bundles, æŠŠ (ã‚), but that's for smaller bundles that can be held with one hand. The æŠŠ counter is becoming uncommon and archaic, though.

Counts: bundles of asparagus, soba noodles, firewood, scallions, green onions, ropes, konbu, noodles, incense sticks, papers, bills, bouquets, sets of newspapers or origami cranes, etc.

ç‰ (ãŸã¾)

ç‰ means ball, bead, and even testicles. As a counter it's used to count round things, such as tomatoes, peaches, heads of lettuce, cabbage, and of course, testicles. It can also be used to count tangled balls of string, and other "ball-shaped" things, even if they're not ball-shaped when taken apart. For example, a ball of yarn could be counted with ç‰. Or even a portion of noodles. Instead of ç‰, though, it's probably more common to use the general counter å€‹. One exception to this is pachinko balls, which are pretty much always counted with ç‰, no matter what.

For one or two balls, use the wago counting method (ã²ã¨ãŸã¾, ãµãŸãŸã¾). After that, it's all kango all the way.

Counts: ball-shaped things; round fruit such as peaches, melons, watermelons, tomatoes, and persimmons; round vegetables such as onions, cabbage, lettuce, and even Chinese cabbage (despite it not being super round); balls of noodles such as yakisoba, udon, soba, ramen, and konnyaku noodles; balls of yarn, balls of wire, pachinko balls, etc.

æ®µ (ã ã‚“)

This counter can count a variety of things, including stairs, steps, shelves, the number of drawers, layers, floors of a bunk bed, stages of a rocket, ranks in martial arts, paragraphs, and even columns. What do these things have in common? Despite being totally different, they also all have pretty distinct layers/levels to them, and they're organized vertically (for the most part).

Counts: steps of stairs, shelves (when multiple shelves are installed vertically), cake tiers, bunk bed levels, drawers (when multiple drawers are installed vertically), stages such as rocket stages, martial arts ranks, Japanese calligraphy ranks, paragraphs, columns, etc.

ç€ (ã¡ã‚ƒã)

This counter is used to count clothesâ€”one coat, ten skirts, etc. But, it is also the ordinal number suffix for first place, second place, etc., in a race.
